Objective: Review and refine an environmental report intended for government submission. Task: As a consultant with expertise in environmental impacts, specifically wastewater treatment, your goal is to edit and enhance the report. The aim is to make the report compelling and persuasive, advocating for the treatment of wastewater outfall into a river. Instructions: Evaluation Criteria: Start by establishing the criteria you'll use to review the report. Consider clarity, persuasiveness, data accuracy, solution viability, and environmental impact understanding. Step-by-Step Review Process: Assessment: Analyze the current state of the report. Identify areas of strength that support the project’s goals and areas of weakness that require improvement. Refinement Ideas: Propose specific edits and improvements. This could include reorganizing content for better flow, enhancing arguments with additional data, clarifying technical descriptions, and suggesting new sections that could strengthen the report's persuasive power. Presentation Enhancements: Offer suggestions on how to make the report more accessible and compelling to government officials. This might involve visual aids, executive summaries, and clear articulation of benefits to both the environment and the community. Editing Recommendations: Provide actionable recommendations for each section of the report. Prioritize changes that would significantly enhance the persuasive quality of the document. Context: The report is in a preliminary draft stage and needs both cosmetic and substantive edits to be deemed professional and convincing. The ultimate goal is to secure government approval for the proposed wastewater treatment project, making a positive impact on the river's environmental health. Parameters: Focus: Emphasize precision, persuasiveness, and professional integrity in your recommendations. Length and Format: Detail your findings and suggestions concisely within an 800-word limit. Structure your feedback by report sections (Introduction, Analysis, Proposed Solutions, etc.) for clarity. Style: Maintain a professional and authoritative tone, suitable for a consultant experienced in environmental matters.

The text to edit:
____________________________________________________________________________
Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant 
Environmental Impact Report 
Date: Tuesday Feb 6, 2024
Update Date: Thursday Feb 8, 2024
Version: 0.5
Status: Rough Draft


Abstract        1
Introduction        2
Environmental, Social & Financial Impact        2
Current Environmental Status        3
Technology Overview        8
Sludge Management and Disposal        10
The Treatment Shaft - A Tested System        11
Legal Compliance        12
Significance of the Project:        13
Conclusion:        16
Addendum:        18
Calculations and Datasheet:        18


Abstract
The Environmental Impact Report for the Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project in Baghdad presents an in-depth analysis of Iraq's critical water management challenges and proposes a sustainable solution. This report synthesizes data from various studies, including the impact of untreated wastewater on the Tigris River and regional health, and introduces an advanced treatment shaft technology designed to significantly enhance water quality. It evaluates the environmental implications of the current scenario, the efficacy of the proposed technology, and its compliance with Iraqi environmental laws, including Law No 27 of 2009 for Protection and Improvement of Environment. The report underscores the necessity of this project in mitigating water pollution, safeguarding public health, and contributing to Iraq's sustainable development.
Introduction
Iraq's struggle with water management, particularly in urban areas like Baghdad's Medical City, necessitates an innovative approach to wastewater treatment. The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project, with a capacity of 150,000 m3/day average to 183,000 m3/day (maximum) is introduced to address these challenges. This report outlines the project’s objectives, detailing the deployment of cutting-edge vertical treatment shaft technology to improve water quality and meet environmental sustainability goals. Emphasizing legal compliance and socio-economic benefits, the report provides an introduction to the current environmental standards, the legislative framework the project will adhere to, the treatment methodology and its expected impact.
Environmental, Social & Financial Impact
Wastewater mismanagement poses significant environmental, social, and financial threats. By contaminating natural water bodies and reducing arable land, it endangers human health and wildlife while undermining economic activities reliant on clean water. This project's investment in advanced treatment will yield substantial benefits by averting ecological damage and fostering economic prosperity through cleaner water resources.  
This process of dumping wastewater into the natural water supply poses hazards not only to human health, but can also have a devastating effect on wildlife, especially for fish and other animals in the water. Harmful substances in water can also get into fields and soil, which results in smaller crop yields for farmers. 
The damage to ecosystems due to excessive wastewater discharges has impacts beyond the environment. Economic impacts, such as pumping waste water without treatment into Dijlah river, will cause losses to the population since river water is used for drinking and manufacturing activities and river banks normally are invested for recreation, commercial and employment opportunities. 
In the economic analysis of this investment, the ecological externalities of the project were monetized, starting from the assumption that the wastewater treatment process is a process that has desired output—treated water. Their estimated value, determined by “shadow prices'', actually represents the avoided damage/costs, i.e., the realized benefit/income for the environment as a result of the removal of pollutants during treatment in the WWTP (Waste Water Treatment Plant).
The difference between the pollution costs for wastewater and the pollution costs for treated water represents the realized savings in the cost of pollution, i.e., environmental benefits. For example, the suspended particles. The final results of the conducted economic cost-benefit analysis unequivocally indicate the full socio-economic justification for the investment. At the same time, the sensitivity analysis proved that the project is resistant to possible changes in input parameters over time.
Current Environmental Status
The water crisis in Iraq sets a critical backdrop for environmental discussions, as highlighted by H.E. Abdul Latif Rashid at the UN Water Conference referencing that over the last 40 years water flows in the Euphrates and Tigris have decreased by 30 to 40%. With a marked reduction in river flows pollution concerns at the Medical City site become more and more important to address.
The aggregated contaminated water from Medical City is seen exiting this sewer into the Tigris river in the image below:  
This pollution is visible on land, as well as from satellite imagery, indicating the severity of the contamination of the river:
 
The environmental status of Medical City outfall has been well researched by the University of Technology Baghdad and the University of Nahrain, see paper reference number ISSN: 1735-3866 


Paper reference number ISSN: 2412-0758. 
In these papers is presented water quality data that indicates that key contaminants such as biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), suspended solids, ammonia, and phosphates are present at levels that surpass legal levels set by Iraqi Laws, such as Law No 27 of 2009 for Protection and Improvement of Environment.
The Iraqi Environmental Protection and Enhancement Law No. 27 for 2009 is the main legal document that outlines the environmental considerations for any project or activity to be carried out in the Country. 
As per the requirements of The Iraqi Environmental protection and Enhancement Law no. 27 for year 2009, our team undertake to fulfill all the requirements such as
1. Conduct an EIA (Environment Impact Analysis) study prior to the commencement of any project activities.
2. Get the prior approval of the Ministry of Environment (MoEn) before starting the project as per articles 10 & 11 of the Law no. 27 for 2009.
3. Provide and implement pollution control measures using clean. technologies, this is to be associated to ensure the proper performance of these control measures, as per article 9 of the same law.
4. Provide tools for measuring the levels of pollutants. Records should be kept and made available to MoEn when needed. If such tools cannot be provided by the establishment, the MoEn performs these measurements, as per article 9 of the same law.
5. Build a database for environmental protection and sustainability, as per article 9 of the same law.
6. Reduce pollution through using renewable energy technologies, as per article 9 of the same law.
7. We also undertake to fulfill the requirements of any other legislation and regulations imposed by the relevant Iraqi government organization for the protection of water resources. [a]

In light of global trends and local data, it becomes evident that strategic improvements in wastewater treatment are required. Enhanced treatment methods are essential to not only address the immediate concerns related to Medical City's outfall but also to contribute to the larger objective of mitigating Iraq's water challenges.
Technology Overview
The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant introduces to Iraq a patented treatment shaft technology, a vertically integrated system designed to occupy much less space (about 20% the size of a conventional Treatment Plant) while delivering high-quality water treatment. Proven effective in reducing pollutants, this technology is a leap forward in meeting and exceeding WHO and Iraqi water discharge standards.  
WET has two technologies for wastewater treatment that provide two levels of treatment, these are:


1. Treatment Shaft (TS) technology for primary treatment that provides skimming, settling, screening and disinfection for most of the pollutants for safe discharge to surface water (Figure 1).
2. Dual Treatment Shaft (DTS) technology for providing (in addition to primary treatment) secondary and treasury treatment for municipal wastewater and for effluent water reuse for restricted irrigation (Figure 2).


 C:\Documents and Settings\sghalib\Desktop\Shaft 3-D\contract5-rev4a-water.jpg 

 8-NoBG.png 

















        Figure 1 – Treatment Shaft                    Figure 2 - Double Treatment Shaft        


It’s an innovative and patented design featuring a vertical Treatment Shaft achieves wastewater treatment objectives at a substantially less area for construction, lower cost than traditional alternatives, while controlling odor and simplifying operations.   The technologies has received many patents in the US, Japan, South Korea and more recently in Iraq.   The Treatment Shaft technology has been proven to treat wastewater discharges and eliminate pollution impact on water resources. 
The vertical Treatment Shaft is a United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) award-winning technology (US EPA PISCES 2006 Award) and listed as an Emerging Technology in the “US EPA Emerging Technologies for Wastewater Treatment and In-Plant Wet Weather Management” Manual in 2013 (see attachment ***).  This award winning technology involves a comprehensive process that includes pre-treatment, primary and secondary treatment phases, and a final disinfection stage. Each phase is designed to efficiently reduce specific pollutants. Modeling the improvements in water markers for the Medical City site we are confident we can meet, and exceed the WHO and Iraqi legal standards for water discharge quality. 
Sludge Management and Disposal


The Vertical Treatment Shaft, when implemented and in operation, will capture almost all the solids (TSS) and organic contaminants (BOD) from going into the river as it is the case currently.  This will be achieved by the primary treatment in the first shaft and secondary treatment using the DAF system in the second shaft.   Skimming and settled primary solids from the first shaft (estimated to be 1.5% dry solids) will be pumped to the sludge storage/thickening tank. The return activated sludge from the DAF’s (expected to be approximately 3% dry solids) will be diverted from the return activated sludge line from each DAF to the sludge storage/thickening tank. Primary sludge and secondary sludge will be thickened in the sludge storage/thickener tank. The combined thickened sludge will pass through dry solids presses, with the dried solids being deposited by conveyor into either a dump body truck or a roll-off container. The remaining effluent discharges will meet the water TSS and BOD limits as stated in the project objectives. The projected amount of solid to be captured and disposed off site is estimated at 17,200 lbs per day which is equivalent to 132,000 gallons per day which will bring huge improvement to water quality in the river.  Dried solids could be treated using dry bed area and could be used as a fertilizer.

Legal Compliance
The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project is set within a robust legal framework that reflects Iraq's long-standing and evolving commitment to environmental stewardship. This includes adherence to historical legislations like Regulation No. (25) of 1967, which underscores Iraq's early initiatives in preserving its water resources. 
The project is a testament to Iraq's enduring and progressive environmental governance. It embodies the principles of historical legislations and aligns with contemporary legal obligations, such as Iraq's commitment to the UN Water Convention, ensuring the project's operations remain within the ambit of national and international environmental mandates.  
Our project prioritizes legal compliance throughout its design and operational phases. We ensure that all aspects of wastewater treatment, from pollutant removal to effluent discharge, adhere to the mandated environmental standards. This commitment extends to regular monitoring and reporting mechanisms, ensuring ongoing compliance and adaptation to any legal updates.
The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project aligns with Iraq's key environmental laws, especially Law No. 27 of 2009. This project not only improves water quality and public health but also follows Iraq's tradition of environmental protection. By using modern technology and practices, it sets an important example of responsible and legal environmental management. It reflects Iraq's ongoing commitment to both its environmental heritage and current goals for sustainable and excellent environmental practices.
Significance of the Project:
The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project not only addresses contemporary environmental challenges but also resonates with Iraq's historical commitment to environmental legislation. Iraq's early initiatives, like the Regulation No. (25) of 1967, laid the foundation for protecting water resources, a commitment further solidified by joining the UN Water Convention. This project continues that legacy, demonstrating Iraq's dedication to sustainable water management and environmental stewardship.
Now Iraq stands at a pivotal moment to reassert its leadership in environmental legislation and implementation. The project is a testament to innovation in wastewater treatment and a crucial step in keeping Iraqi citizens healthy and safe. By reducing healthcare costs and protecting water resources, the project aligns with Iraq's legal structures, and its commitment to environmental excellence.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, the Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project stands as a pivotal initiative in Iraq's journey towards sustainable environmental management. This report has outlined the pressing environmental challenges faced by the Medical City area, introduced an advanced treatment shaft technology to tackle these issues, and confirmed the project's strict adherence to Iraq's environmental laws.
The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant is a critical step towards sustainable water management in Iraq. This report has highlighted the urgency of environmental challenges in the Medical City area and introduced a viable technological solution that aligns with Iraq's robust environmental regulations. As a symbol of progress, this project marks Iraq's advancement in environmental stewardship and sustainable development.
Finally, this report provides significant proof and justification of the feasibility and cost and land saving advantages that our joint venture team is offering through our EPA (Environmental Protection Agency USA) award winning and patented vertical shaft Wastewater Treatment Technology Solution.

The "Environmental Impact Report" for the Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project is extensive and covers various aspects crucial for its evaluation. Here's a structured review and refinement approach based on the outlined criteria:

### Evaluation Criteria for Review
1. **Clarity**: Assessing the report's language and structure for easy comprehension.
2. **Persuasiveness**: Evaluating the strength of arguments supporting the project.
3. **Data Accuracy**: Verifying the correctness and relevance of data presented.
4. **Solution Viability**: Analyzing the feasibility and effectiveness of proposed solutions.
5. **Understanding of Environmental Impact**: Examining the depth of environmental analysis and compliance with laws.

### Step-by-Step Review Process

#### Assessment
- **Strengths**:
  - **Comprehensive Coverage**: The report thoroughly discusses various aspects like technology overview, legal compliance, and environmental impacts.
  - **Data Utilization**: Effective use of studies and data to underline the current environmental issues and the necessity for the project.

- **Weaknesses**:
  - **Technical Jargon**: Overuse of technical terms might hinder comprehension for non-experts.
  - **Repetitive Content**: Some sections appear redundant, particularly in the legal compliance and project significance areas.

#### Refinement Ideas
1. **Reorganize Content**: Streamline the report for better flow. Combine the 'Legal Compliance' and 'Significance of the Project' sections to avoid repetition.
2. **Enhance Arguments**: Introduce more recent studies or data, especially regarding the success of similar projects elsewhere, to strengthen the case.
3. **Clarify Technical Descriptions**: Simplify technical jargon and explain concepts in layman's terms for broader accessibility.
4. **New Sections**: Consider adding a 'Community Engagement' section to discuss how the project involves and benefits the local community.

#### Presentation Enhancements
1. **Visual Aids**: Use infographics to summarize key points, especially in the technology overview and environmental impact sections.
2. **Executive Summary**: Develop a concise and compelling executive summary highlighting the main points and benefits of the project.
3. **Benefits Articulation**: Clearly articulate the benefits to the environment and community in a separate section or a highlighted box.

#### Editing Recommendations
- **Introduction**: Shorten and focus more on the project's relevance and objectives.
- **Environmental Impact**: Enhance the argument with more recent environmental data and comparative analysis with other regions/countries.
- **Technology Overview**: Simplify technical terms and use diagrams to illustrate how the technology works.
- **Legal Compliance**: Merge with 'Significance of the Project' and streamline the content to avoid repetition.

### Conclusion
The report is detailed and informative but requires refinements for clarity, conciseness, and persuasiveness. Focusing on simplifying technical language, enhancing visual presentation, and emphasizing the project's benefits will make the report more compelling for government approval.

Abstract
The Environmental Impact Report for the Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project in Baghdad presents an in-depth analysis of Iraq's critical water management challenges and proposes a sustainable solution. This report synthesizes data from various studies, including the impact of untreated wastewater on the Tigris River and regional health, and introduces an advanced treatment shaft technology designed to significantly enhance water quality. It evaluates the environmental implications of the current scenario, the efficacy of the proposed technology, and its compliance with Iraqi environmental laws, including Law No 27 of 2009 for Protection and Improvement of Environment. The report underscores the necessity of this project in mitigating water pollution, safeguarding public health, and contributing to Iraq's sustainable development.
Introduction
Iraq's struggle with water management, particularly in urban areas like Baghdad's Medical City, necessitates an innovative approach to wastewater treatment. The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project, with a capacity of 150,000 m3/day average to 183,000 m3/day (maximum) is introduced to address these challenges. This report outlines the project’s objectives, detailing the deployment of cutting-edge vertical treatment shaft technology to improve water quality and meet environmental sustainability goals. Emphasizing legal compliance and socio-economic benefits, the report provides an introduction to the current environmental standards, the legislative framework the project will adhere to, the treatment methodology and its expected impact.
Environmental, Social & Financial Impact
Wastewater mismanagement poses significant environmental, social, and financial threats. By contaminating natural water bodies and reducing arable land, it endangers human health and wildlife while undermining economic activities reliant on clean water. This project's investment in advanced treatment will yield substantial benefits by averting ecological damage and fostering economic prosperity through cleaner water resources.  
This process of dumping wastewater into the natural water supply poses hazards not only to human health, but can also have a devastating effect on wildlife, especially for fish and other animals in the water. Harmful substances in water can also get into fields and soil, which results in smaller crop yields for farmers. 
The damage to ecosystems due to excessive wastewater discharges has impacts beyond the environment. Economic impacts, such as pumping waste water without treatment into Dijlah river, will cause losses to the population since river water is used for drinking and manufacturing activities and river banks normally are invested for recreation, commercial and employment opportunities. 
In the economic analysis of this investment, the ecological externalities of the project were monetized, starting from the assumption that the wastewater treatment process is a process that has desired output—treated water. Their estimated value, determined by “shadow prices'', actually represents the avoided damage/costs, i.e., the realized benefit/income for the environment as a result of the removal of pollutants during treatment in the WWTP (Waste Water Treatment Plant).
The difference between the pollution costs for wastewater and the pollution costs for treated water represents the realized savings in the cost of pollution, i.e., environmental benefits. For example, the suspended particles. The final results of the conducted economic cost-benefit analysis unequivocally indicate the full socio-economic justification for the investment. At the same time, the sensitivity analysis proved that the project is resistant to possible changes in input parameters over time.

Technology Overview
The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant introduces to Iraq a patented treatment shaft technology, a vertically integrated system designed to occupy much less space (about 20% the size of a conventional Treatment Plant) while delivering high-quality water treatment. Proven effective in reducing pollutants, this technology is a leap forward in meeting and exceeding WHO and Iraqi water discharge standards.  
WET has two technologies for wastewater treatment that provide two levels of treatment, these are:

Treatment Shaft (TS) technology for primary treatment that provides skimming, settling, screening and disinfection for most of the pollutants for safe discharge to surface water (Figure 1).
Dual Treatment Shaft (DTS) technology for providing (in addition to primary treatment) secondary and treasury treatment for municipal wastewater and for effluent water reuse for restricted irrigation (Figure 2).











	Figure 1 – Treatment Shaft		    Figure 2 - Double Treatment Shaft	

It’s an innovative and patented design featuring a vertical Treatment Shaft achieves wastewater treatment objectives at a substantially less area for construction, lower cost than traditional alternatives, while controlling odor and simplifying operations.   The technologies has received many patents in the US, Japan, South Korea and more recently in Iraq.   The Treatment Shaft technology has been proven to treat wastewater discharges and eliminate pollution impact on water resources. 
The vertical Treatment Shaft is a United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) award-winning technology (US EPA PISCES 2006 Award) and listed as an Emerging Technology in the “US EPA Emerging Technologies for Wastewater Treatment and In-Plant Wet Weather Management” Manual in 2013 (see attachment ***).  This award winning technology involves a comprehensive process that includes pre-treatment, primary and secondary treatment phases, and a final disinfection stage. Each phase is designed to efficiently reduce specific pollutants. Modeling the improvements in water markers for the Medical City site we are confident we can meet, and exceed the WHO and Iraqi legal standards for water discharge quality. 
Sludge Management and Disposal

The Vertical Treatment Shaft, when implemented and in operation, will capture almost all the solids (TSS) and organic contaminants (BOD) from going into the river as it is the case currently.  This will be achieved by the primary treatment in the first shaft and secondary treatment using the DAF system in the second shaft.   Skimming and settled primary solids from the first shaft (estimated to be 1.5% dry solids) will be pumped to the sludge storage/thickening tank. The return activated sludge from the DAF’s (expected to be approximately 3% dry solids) will be diverted from the return activated sludge line from each DAF to the sludge storage/thickening tank. Primary sludge and secondary sludge will be thickened in the sludge storage/thickener tank. The combined thickened sludge will pass through dry solids presses, with the dried solids being deposited by conveyor into either a dump body truck or a roll-off container. The remaining effluent discharges will meet the water TSS and BOD limits as stated in the project objectives. The projected amount of solid to be captured and disposed off site is estimated at 17,200 lbs per day which is equivalent to 132,000 gallons per day which will bring huge improvement to water quality in the river.
